item.title: My truck!
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:18, topic:458355”][quote author=(Anthony) link=topic=561277.msg4096746#msg4096746 date=1346947735]

Well, java conventions are fucking lame anyway. I like the superior C++ conventions where class data members look like this m_name.

that’s hungarian notation, not “c++ conventions”.
[/quote]

Hey stupid guy. The m_name style is for class data members, m stands for member. Now go google what hungarian notation is.[/quote]
i know what it stands for, it’s not “c++ conventions”. in fact, the gcc c++ conventions say class data members should end with an underscore.
http://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/CppConventions

Read full topic

item.title: My truck!
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:18, topic:458355”][quote author=(Anthony) link=topic=561277.msg4096746#msg4096746 date=1346947735]

Well, java conventions are fucking lame anyway. I like the superior C++ conventions where class data members look like this m_name.

that’s hungarian notation, not “c++ conventions”.
[/quote]

Hey stupid guy. The m_name style is for class data members, m stands for member. Now go google what hungarian notation is.[/quote]

Hungarian notation is an identifier naming convention in computer programming, in which the name of a variable or function indicates its type or intended use.

it is regarded as a form of hungarian notation when we follow wikipedia’s definition. the m_ prefix makes it explicit that a certain variable is a class member, and should be used as such.

Read full topic

item.title: My truck!
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“meiscooldude, post:8, topic:458355”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=561277.msg4095143#msg4095143 date=1346758716]

It doesn’t follow official Java conventions but it follows the conventions of the textbook I’m using, so I’m doing that for now.

And thanks. What’s the difference between importing a class at the top of your code and adding it as an external archive?

what shitty textbook teachest java and does not follow conventions?
[/quote]

Oracle’s inherited conventions for Java in my honest opinion suck. Besides, you are supposed to follow whatever conventions are currently necessary for the time being. If your teacher wants you to follow the textbooks conventions, follow them. If you get a job that has different conventions, follow them. There is a reason most IDE’s allow you to change how they go about auto-formatting.

I personally follow a hybrid of conventions that I’ve used over the years that focuses on enforcing an 80 character limit per line so I can print my code without a crap ton of unreadable line-breaks.

Also, Java’s conventions are ancient and where originally enforced by a Syntactical God-King from Egypt… Here is proof:

Notice how the method heading matches up with the Egyptians head and the method body match up with his body. And camelCase is based of camels (which are from Egypt)[/quote]

No.

Read full topic

item.title: My truck!
item.dc:creator: @meiscooldude meiscooldude
item.description:
@meiscooldude wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:4, topic:458355”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=561277.msg4095116#msg4095116 date=1346755996]
It doesn’t follow official Java conventions but it follows the conventions of the textbook I’m using, so I’m doing that for now.

And thanks. What’s the difference between importing a class at the top of your code and adding it as an external archive?
[/quote]
what shitty textbook teachest java and does not follow conventions?[/quote]

Oracle’s inherited conventions for Java in my honest opinion suck. Besides, you are supposed to follow whatever conventions are currently necessary for the time being. If your teacher wants you to follow the textbooks conventions, follow them. If you get a job that has different conventions, follow them. There is a reason most IDE’s allow you to change how they go about auto-formatting.

I personally follow a hybrid of conventions that I’ve used over the years that focuses on enforcing an 80 character limit per line so I can print my code without a crap ton of unreadable line-breaks.

Also, Java’s conventions are ancient and where originally enforced by a Syntactical God-King from Egypt… Here is proof:

Notice how the method heading matches up with the Egyptians head and the method body match up with his body. And camelCase is based of camels (which are from Egypt)

Read full topic

item.title: My truck!
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:3, topic:458355”]It doesn’t follow official Java conventions but it follows the conventions of the textbook I’m using, so I’m doing that for now.

And thanks. What’s the difference between importing a class at the top of your code and adding it as an external archive?[/quote]
Those are two different things, a class needs to be on the classpath of your project to be able to import it.
When you’re working in a project in your IDE of choice, all the files compiled under the project are automatically included on the classpath.

If you’re using some external library, you need to include it on the classpath; generally most IDEs do this for you when you drag a library under the project’s library “folder”.

Read full topic
